edu.rit.pj2

Class Task

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.pj2.Task
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    BCASmp, CCASeq, CCASmp, HamCycSeq, HamCycSmp, KnapsackBnbGpu, KnapsackExhGpu, MandelbrotSeq, MandelbrotSeq3, MandelbrotSmp, MandelbrotSmp2, MandelbrotSmp3, MapperTask, MineCoinSeq, MineCoinSmp, MinVerCovSeq, MinVerCovSeq2, MinVerCovSeq3, MinVerCovSmp, MinVerCovSmp2, MinVerCovSmp3, OuterProductGpu, OuterProductSeq, PiGpu, PiGpu2, PiSeq, PiSmp, PiSmp2, Powers, PrimeSeq, PrimeSmp, ReducerTask, StatTestSeq, StatTestSmp, Test01, Test01, Test02, Test02, Test03, Test03, Test04, Test04, Test05, Test05, Test06, Test06, TotientSeq, TotientSmp, TotientSmp2, WalkSackGpu, ZombieGpu, ZombieGpu2, ZombieSeq, ZombieSmp

    public abstract class Task
extends Object
    Class Task is the abstract base class for a PJ2 task. A PJ2 parallel program is either a single task (a subclass of class Task) or is a number of tasks grouped together into a job (a subclass of class Job). A PJ2 program is executed by running the PJ2 launcher program, class pj2.

    Programming a task. To set up a task:

    • Write a subclass of class Task.

    • Optionally, specify the task's initial properties by overriding the initialThreads(), initialSchedule(), and/or initialChunk() methods.

    • Optionally, specify the node capabilities required to execute the task by overriding the nodeNameRequired(), coresRequired(), and/or gpusRequired() methods.

    • In the Task subclass's main() method, write the code for the task's computation.

    The task's computation can contain sequential statements executed by a single thread, interspersed with parallel statements executed by multiple threads in parallel. The possible parallel statements are:

    • Work sharing parallel for loop, integer loop index (see parallelFor(int,int))
    • Work sharing parallel for loop, long integer loop index (see parallelFor(long,long))
    • Work sharing parallel for loop over a series of work items in a WorkQueue (see parallelFor(WorkQueue))
    • Parallel section group, multiple different sections (see parallelDo(Section...))
    • Parallel section group, multiple copies of the same section (see parallelDo(int,Section))
    • Worker portion of a master-worker cluster parallel for loop (see workerFor())

    The task's computation can query the task's properties by calling the threads(), schedule(), chunk(), nodeName(), cores(), and gpus() methods. The task's computation can alter the task's initial properties by calling the threads(int), schedule(Schedule), and chunk(int) methods. While the task's computation can alter the task's nodeName, cores, and gpus properties, doing so has no effect once the task has started.

    Shared variables used by the thread executing the sequential statements and by the threads executing the parallel statements are typically declared as fields of the Task subclass. This puts the shared variables in scope both for code in the main() method and for code in the parallel statements.

    Running a task. To run a task, type this command:

    $ java pj2 MainTask arg ...

    The above command runs class MainTask, a subclass of class Task. Replace MainTask with the fully-qualified class name of the desired task subclass. The pj2 program creates an instance of the task subclass, then calls the task's main() method, passing in an array of the command line argument strings (zero or more). The main() method carries out the computation.

    Tasks in a job. A PJ2 task may be executed as part of a Job. The job maintains a repository of Tuples known as tuple space. The job's execution is driven by firing the job's Rules, based on tuples that are written into tuple space. Each rule has an associated task group consisting of one or more tasks. There are three kinds of rules:

    • Start rule—A rule that fires once when the job starts.

    • On-demand rule—A rule that fires when a certain tuple or tuples are present in tuple space.

    • Finish rule—A rule that fires once when the job finishes.

    When a rule fires, for each task in the rule's task group, an instance of the task is constructed, and the task's main() method is called to carry out the task's computation. For further information about the criteria for firing rules and the actions performed when firing rules, see class Rule.

    The task can determine the number of tasks in its task group by calling the groupSize() method. The task can determine its own rank in its task group by calling the taskRank() method. The tasks in a rule's task group are assigned successive ranks, starting with 0, in the order the tasks were added to the rule. The task's rank uniquely distinguishes the task from all other tasks in the task group.

    The task may get input tuples in several ways. The task may take tuples out of tuple space by calling the takeTuple() or tryToTakeTuple() methods, specifying a template for matching the desired tuple. The task may read tuples, without taking them out of tuple space, by calling the readTuple() or tryToReadTuple() methods, specifying a template for matching the desired tuple. The task may add a TupleListener by calling the addTupleListener() method. A task launched by an on-demand rule may obtain one of the rule's matching tuples by calling the getMatchingTuple() method.

    The task may put output tuples into tuple space by calling the putTuple() method. Such tuples may trigger further rules to fire and further tasks to be executed. The task may also specify that multiple copies of a tuple are to be put into tuple space.

    The task must not alter its input tuples. If an output tuple needs to be the same as an input tuple but with modifications, create a copy of the input tuple and modify that.

    I/O in a task. If a task is not running as part of a Job, code in the task can print on System.out or System.err, and the printouts appear on the task's process's console as usual. The printouts actually appear on the console when the task terminates; to make the printouts appear earlier, call System.out.flush() or System.err.flush(). Code in such a task can also read and write files as usual.

    If a task is launched by a Job, code in the task can print on System.out or System.err, and the printouts are automatically redirected to the job's process's console. The printouts actually appear on the console when the task terminates; to make the printouts appear earlier, call System.out.flush() or System.err.flush().

    For other I/O, such as reading from the job's standard input, reading files, and writing files, the task might need to run in the job's process. This would be necessary, for example, if tasks running on separate nodes do not run in the user's account and so cannot access the user's files. For further information, see class Job.

    JVM heap size in a task. If a task is not running as part of a Job, you can specify the maximum JVM heap size with a flag on the java command. For example, to get a 2-gigabyte heap, type this command:

    java -Xmx2000m pj2 MainTask arg ...

    If a task is launched by a Job, you can specify the maximum JVM heap size by calling the jvmFlags() method in the TaskSpec in the Rule that launches the task. For further information, see class Job.

    Abnormal termination. If code in a task throws an exception that propagates out of the main() method, the pj2 program prints an exception stack trace and terminates.

    Code in a task must not call the System.exit() method. If a task needs to terminate itself, the task should throw an exception that propagates out of every method without being caught, such as a TerminateException or any other runtime exception. The exception's detail message can explain why the task terminated. This exception propagates out of the main() method and causes the pj2 program to terminate.

      • fixed

        public static final Schedule fixed
        Fixed schedule. The iterations are partitioned into as many chunks as there are threads. Each chunk is the same size (except possibly the last chunk). Each thread performs a different chunk of iterations. The chunk property is not used.

        A fixed schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes the same amount of time, so load balancing is not needed; and when each thread should do a contiguous range of loop indexes.

        See Also:
        Schedule.fixed

      • leapfrog

        public static final Schedule leapfrog
        Leapfrog schedule. Let the loop index lower bound be L and the number of threads be K; then thread 0 performs the iterations for indexes L, L+K, L+2K, ...; thread 1 performs the iterations for indexes L+1, L+1+K, L+1+2K, ...; thread 2 performs the iterations for indexes L+2, L+2+K, L+2+2K, ...; and so on. The chunk property is not used.

        A leapfrog schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes the same amount of time, so load balancing is not needed; and when each thread should do noncontiguous loop indexes with a stride of K.

        See Also:
        Schedule.leapfrog

      • dynamic

        public static final Schedule dynamic
        Dynamic schedule. The iterations are partitioned into chunks. Each chunk is the same size (except possibly the last chunk) as specified by the chunk property. If the chunk property is STANDARD_CHUNK, a chunk size of 1 is used. The threads execute the chunks in a dynamic fashion: when a thread has finished executing a chunk, the thread gets the next available chunk and executes it.

        A dynamic schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes a different amount of time, so load balancing is needed. However, be careful when choosing the chunk size. A smaller chunk size can yield a better balanced load; a larger chunk size requires less thread synchronization overhead.

        See Also:
        Schedule.dynamic

      • proportional

        public static final Schedule proportional
        Proportional schedule. The iterations are partitioned into chunks. Each chunk is the same size (except possibly the last chunk). The chunk property specifies the chunk factor. If the chunk property is STANDARD_CHUNK, a chunk factor of 10 is used. The number of chunks is the number of threads times the chunk factor. The chunk size is the number of iterations divided by the number of chunks. The threads execute the chunks in a dynamic fashion: when a thread has finished executing a chunk, the thread gets the next available chunk and executes it.

        A proportional schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes a different amount of time, so load balancing is needed. However, be careful when choosing the chunk factor. A larger chunk factor can yield a better balanced load; a smaller chunk factor requires less thread synchronization overhead.

        See Also:
        Schedule.proportional

      • guided

        public static final Schedule guided
        Guided schedule. The iterations are partitioned into chunks. The chunks are of different sizes; earlier chunks are larger, later chunks are smaller. The minimum chunk size is specified by the chunk property. If the chunk property is STANDARD_CHUNK, a minimum chunk size of 1 is used. The threads execute the chunks in a dynamic fashion: when a thread has finished executing a chunk, the thread gets the next available chunk and executes it.

        A guided schedule is appropriate when each loop iteration takes a different amount of time, so load balancing is needed. However, be careful when choosing the minimum chunk size. A smaller minimum chunk size can yield a better balanced load; a larger minimum chunk size requires less thread synchronization overhead.

        See Also:
        Schedule.guided

      • main

        public abstract void main(String[] args)
                   throws Exception
        Perform this task's computation.

        Warning: The main() method is intended to be called only by the pj2 launcher program. Do not call the main() method yourself.

        Parameters:
        args - Array of zero or more command line argument strings.
        Throws:
        Exception - The main() method can throw any exception.

      • threads

        public void threads(int threads)
        Set this task's threads property. The threads property specifies the number of threads that will execute a parallel for loop.
        Parameters:
        threads - Number of threads (≥ 1), THREADS_EQUALS_CORES, or DEFAULT_THREADS.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if threads is illegal.
        See Also:
        threads(), actualThreads()

      • threads

        public int threads()
        Get this task's threads property. The threads property specifies the number of threads that will execute a parallel for loop. The default is THREADS_EQUALS_CORES, indicating that a parallel for loop will be executed by as many threads as there are cores on the machine.

        Note: The threads() method returns the threads property setting, which may be THREADS_EQUALS_CORES. For the actual number of threads, see the actualThreads() method.

        Returns:
        Number of threads (≥ 1), or THREADS_EQUALS_CORES.
        See Also:
        threads(int), actualThreads()

      • actualThreads

        public int actualThreads()
        Get the number of threads that will execute a parallel for loop.

        Note: If the threads property is THREADS_EQUALS_CORES, the actualThreads() method returns the actual number of threads that will execute a parallel for loop, namely the number of cores on the machine. For the threads property setting, see the threads() method.

        Returns:
        Number of threads (≥ 1).
        See Also:
        threads(int), threads()

        See Also:

      • parallelFor

        public IntParallelForLoop parallelFor(int lb,
                             int ub)
        Execute a work sharing parallel for loop with a loop index of type int. The loop index goes from the given lower bound to the given upper bound. For further information, see classes ParallelForLoop and IntParallelForLoop.
        Parameters:
        lb - Loop index lower bound (inclusive).
        ub - Loop index upper bound (inclusive).

      • parallelDo

        public void parallelDo(Section... sections)
        Execute the given group of sections in parallel. The sections' run() methods are called simultaneously, each by a different thread. For further information, see class Section.
        Parameters:
        sections - Sections to be executed in parallel.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if no sections are specified.

      • parallelDo

        public void parallelDo(int K,
              Section section)
        Execute the given number of copies of the given section in parallel. The copies are created by cloning the given section object. The sections' run() methods are called simultaneously, each by a different thread. For further information, see class Section.
        Parameters:
        K - Number of sections (≥ 1).
        section - Section to be executed in parallel.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if K < 1.
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if section is null.

      • workerFor

        public WorkerParallelForLoop workerFor()
        Execute the worker portion of a master-worker cluster parallel for loop. To complete the master-worker cluster parallel for loop, the Job's main() method must call the masterFor(int,int,Class) or masterFor(long,long,Class) method. For further information, see class WorkerParallelForLoop.
        Returns:
        Worker parallel for loop object.

      • matchingTupleCount

        public int matchingTupleCount()
        Returns the number of matching tuples for this task. For a task launched by an on-demand Rule, the number of matching tuples is the number of templates specified in the rule. For a task launched by a start rule or a finish rule, there are no matching tuples.
        Returns:
        Number of matching tuples.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if this task is not executing as part of a job.

      • getMatchingTuple

        public Tuple getMatchingTuple(int i)
        Get the given matching tuple for this task. The tuple index denotes one of the templates in the on-demand Rule that launched this task. This method returns the tuple that matched the template at the given index.

        The task must not alter its input tuples. If an output tuple needs to be the same as an input tuple but with modifications, create a copy of the input tuple and modify that.

        Parameters:
        i - Tuple index in the range 0 .. matchingTupleCount()−1.
        Returns:
        Matching tuple at index i.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if this task is not executing as part of a job.
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if i is out of bounds.

      • takeTuple

        public <T extends Tuple> T takeTuple(T template)
                          throws IOException
        Take a tuple that matches the given template out of tuple space. If there are no matching tuples in tuple space, this method blocks until a matching tuple appears in tuple space. If there is more than one matching tuple in tuple space, one of the matching tuples is chosen in an unspecified manner.

        The task must not alter its input tuples. If an output tuple needs to be the same as an input tuple but with modifications, create a copy of the input tuple and modify that.

        Type Parameters:
        T - Tuple data type.
        Parameters:
        template - Template.
        Returns:
        Tuple that matches the template.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if this task is not executing as part of a job.
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if template is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • tryToTakeTuple

        public <T extends Tuple> T tryToTakeTuple(T template)
                               throws IOException
        Try to take a tuple that matches the given template out of tuple space. If there are no matching tuples in tuple space, this method returns null without blocking. If there is more than one matching tuple in tuple space, one of the matching tuples is chosen in an unspecified manner.

        The task must not alter its input tuples. If an output tuple needs to be the same as an input tuple but with modifications, create a copy of the input tuple and modify that.

        Type Parameters:
        T - Tuple data type.
        Parameters:
        template - Template.
        Returns:
        Tuple that matches the template, or null if none.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if this task is not executing as part of a job.
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if template is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • readTuple

        public <T extends Tuple> T readTuple(T template)
                          throws IOException
        Read a tuple that matches the given template. If there are no matching tuples in tuple space, this method blocks until a matching tuple appears in tuple space. If there is more than one matching tuple in tuple space, one of the matching tuples is chosen in an unspecified manner. The matching tuple remains in tuple space.

        The task must not alter its input tuples. If an output tuple needs to be the same as an input tuple but with modifications, create a copy of the input tuple and modify that.

        Type Parameters:
        T - Tuple data type.
        Parameters:
        template - Template.
        Returns:
        Tuple that matches the template.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if this task is not executing as part of a job.
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if template is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • tryToReadTuple

        public <T extends Tuple> T tryToReadTuple(T template)
                               throws IOException
        Try to read a tuple that matches the given template. If there are no matching tuples in tuple space, this method returns null without blocking. If there is more than one matching tuple in tuple space, one of the matching tuples is chosen in an unspecified manner. The matching tuple remains in tuple space.

        The task must not alter its input tuples. If an output tuple needs to be the same as an input tuple but with modifications, create a copy of the input tuple and modify that.

        Type Parameters:
        T - Tuple data type.
        Parameters:
        template - Template.
        Returns:
        Tuple that matches the template, or null if none.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if this task is not executing as part of a job.
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if template is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • addTupleListener

        public void addTupleListener(TupleListener<?> listener)
                      throws IOException
        Add the given tuple listener to this task. The tuple listener specifies a template and an operation, either read or take. When there is a tuple in tuple space that matches the template, the tuple listener is triggered, the matching tuple is read or taken, and the matching tuple is passed to the tuple listener's run() method. The tuple listener will not be triggered again. For further information, see class TupleListener.

        The task must not alter its input tuples. If an output tuple needs to be the same as an input tuple but with modifications, create a copy of the input tuple and modify that.

        Parameters:
        listener - Tuple listener.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if this task is not executing as part of a job.
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if listener is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • putTuple

        public void putTuple(Tuple tuple)
              throws IOException
        Put the given output tuple into tuple space.
        Parameters:
        tuple - Output tuple.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if this task is not executing as part of a job.
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if tuple is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • putTuple

        public void putTuple(int copies,
            Tuple tuple)
              throws IOException
        Put multiple copies of the given output tuple into tuple space. If copies = 0, this method does nothing.
        Parameters:
        copies - Number of copies (≥ 0).
        tuple - Output tuple.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if this task is not executing as part of a job.
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if tuple is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if copies < 0.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • initialThreads

        protected static int initialThreads()
        Get this task class's initial threads property. When a TaskSpec is created for this task class, the task spec's threads property is initialized to the value the initialThreads() method returns. The threads property specifies the number of threads that will execute a parallel for loop.

        In the Task base class, this method returns DEFAULT_THREADS, which indicates that a parallel for loop will be executed by as many threads as there are cores on the machine. A subclass can override this method to return something else.

        Returns:
        Number of threads (≥ 1), THREADS_EQUALS_CORES, or DEFAULT_THREADS.

      • initialSchedule

        protected static Schedule initialSchedule()
        Get this task class's initial schedule property. When a TaskSpec is created for this task class, the task spec's schedule property is initialized to the value the initialSchedule() method returns. The schedule property, along with the chunk property, specifies how the iterations of a parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing the parallel for loop. Refer to enum Schedule for descriptions of the possible schedules.

        In the Task base class, this method returns DEFAULT_SCHEDULE, which indicates a fixed schedule. A subclass can override this method to return something else.

        Returns:
        Parallel for loop schedule, or DEFAULT_SCHEDULE.

      • initialChunk

        protected static int initialChunk()
        Get this task class's initial chunk property. When a TaskSpec is created for this task class, the task spec's chunk property is initialized to the value the initialChunk() method returns. The chunk property, along with the schedule property, specifies how the iterations of a parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing the parallel for loop. Refer to enum Schedule for descriptions of the possible schedules.

        In the Task base class, this method returns DEFAULT_CHUNK, which indicates the standard chunk size for the schedule property; see enum Schedule for further information. A subclass can override this method to return something else.

        Returns:
        Chunk size (≥ 1), STANDARD_CHUNK, or DEFAULT_CHUNK.

      • nodeNameRequired

        protected static String nodeNameRequired()
        Get this task class's required nodeName property. When a TaskSpec is created for this task class, the task spec's nodeName property is set to the value the nodeNameRequired() method returns. The nodeName property specifies the name of the cluster node on which the task must run.

        In the Task base class, this method returns DEFAULT_NODE_NAME, which indicates that the task can run on any node of the cluster. A subclass can override this method to return something else.

        Returns:
        Node name, ANY_NODE_NAME, or DEFAULT_NODE_NAME.

      • coresRequired

        protected static int coresRequired()
        Get this task class's required cores property. When a TaskSpec is created for this task class, the task spec's cores property is set to the value the coresRequired() method returns. The cores property specifies the number of CPU cores the task requires.

        In the Task base class, this method returns DEFAULT_CORES, which indicates that the task requires all the cores on the node. A subclass can override this method to return something else.

        Returns:
        Number of cores (≥ 1), ALL_CORES, or DEFAULT_CORES.

      • gpusRequired

        protected static int gpusRequired()
        Get this task class's requred gpus property. When a TaskSpec is created for this task class, the task spec's gpus property is set to the value the gpusRequired() method returns. The gpus property specifies the number of GPU accelerators the task requires.

        In the Task base class, this method returns DEFAULT_GPUS, which indicates that the task requires no GPU accelerators. A subclass can override this method to return something else.

        Returns:
        Number of GPUs (≥ 0), ALL_GPUS, or DEFAULT_GPUS.
